lab 22 introduction previous this lab, coincident with the gynecology and obstetrics block, includes four exercises designed to review the clinical anatomy of the pelvis and perineum. while the anatomy of both sexes will be studied, that of the female will be emphasized. next the bony pelvis is the skeleton of two connected regions, the pelvis and the perineum. the pelvic cavity opens superiorly into the abdominal cavity. the floor of the pelvis includes the muscular pelvic diaphragm. the contents of the pelvis are related to the urinary, gastrointestinal and reproductive systems. in both sexes, the urethra and anal canal pass through openings in the pelvic diaphragm. in the female, the vagina passes through as well. below the pelvic diaphragm is the body region between the thighs, the perineum. the perineum contains the external genitalia, the penis and scrotum in the male and the vulva in the female, and the terminus of both the genitourinary and gastrointestinal systems.

lab instructions previous next 9:00 - 9:40 am 9:40 - 10:20 am 10:20 - 11:00 am 11:00 - 11:40 am pairs 1 23.1 perineum 23.2 imaging 23.3 pelvic wall 23.4 pelvic viscera pairs 2 23.2 23.3 23.4 23.1 pairs 3 23.3 23.4 23.1 23.2 pairs 4 23.4 23.1 23.2 23.3 this content will be tested on the gyne and sex and gender-based medicine mastery exercise. prepare by reviewing the contents of the pre-lab slm and completing the quiz associated with it. this ensures not only that you are properly prepared for the lab for your benefit, but that you have earned the privilege of learning anatomy through cadaveric study. the lab is three hours long and consists of four practical exercises. you will spend 40 minutes on each exercise. there is no dissection. you will work with models, images, bones and prosections. at 11:40, when you have finished rotating through the four stations, you will clean up the lab in preparation for leaving. this includes proper moistening, wrapping, bagging and tagging of all wet specimens, and wiping down all surfaces with cleaning solution. at 11:50, an app-based rat will take place. it will consist of 3 questions on each section of 21a for a total of 12 questions; i.e. the lab rat is being held at the end of the lab rather than the beginning. there is a lot of content to review, and the time spent studying specimens in the lab will help to consolidate it in preparation for the rat.

author & emodule development: barbara ballyk, ph.d. associate professor, teaching stream division of anatomy, department of surgery faculty of medicine, university of toronto acknowledgements previous brand design: janet koecher, discovery commons university of toronto 2017

22.1 the perineum previous specimens a model of the bony pelvis a model of the pelvis with organs prosected male and female perinea next what youll need: instructions pairs 1, who start at this station will unwrap the prosections. the prosections must be kept moist by students throughout the lab period. pairs 2, who finish with this station, must moisten, wrap, bag and tag each specimen and return it to the bin.

22.1 objectives next previous when you have learned the content of this emodule, you will be able to identify and describe the: boundaries and subdivisions of the perineum. contents of the anal triangle. contents of the deep and superficial pouches of the urogenital triangle in the male and female. 2

22a introduction previous the pelvic floor is composed of skeletal muscle, the pelvic diaphragm, and connective tissue. the pelvic diaphragm includes the levator ani. the pelvic floor separates the pelvis, superiorly, from the perineum, inferiorly. components of the genitourinary and digestive tracts pass through the pelvic floor, from the pelvis into the perineum. the perineum is enclosed within the pelvic outlet, which is defined by the pubic symphysis, anteriorly, the coccyx, posteriorly and the ischial tuberosities, laterally. for descriptive purposes, an imaginary line connecting the two ischial tuberosities divides the perineum into a urogenital (ug) triangle, anteriorly, and an anal triangle, posteriorly. in both sexes, the ug triangle serves to anchor the external genitalia and accommodates the passage of the urethra. in women, it also accommodates the opening of the vagina. the anal triangle contains the anal canal. the perineum is the body region between the thighs and inferior to the pelvic floor. 23.1 the sacrospinous and sacrotuberous ligament previous 2a 22.1 borders and landmarks of the perineum next previous 3 to review the introduction to the perineum, click here: you have been provided with a bony pelvis, either real or a model. you have also been provided with a pelvis model with organs. orient the bony pelvis dorsal down and look at it from the inferior aspect, as illustrated. tas k identify the landmarks that define the pelvic outlet. these are the inferior border of the pubic symphysis, the tip of the coccyx and the left and right ischial tuberosities. identify the conjoint rami, formed by the inferior pubic and ischial rami. the pubic arch is formed by the left and right conjoint rami and defines the anterolateral borders of the perineum. using the pelvis model, identify the tas k sacrotuberous and sacrospinous ligaments . identify the greater and lesser sciatic foramina. identify the obturator foramen and the obturator membrane. orient the model as in the accompanying diagram next to the bony pelvis and recognize that the sacrotuberous ligaments, bilaterally, form the posterolateral borders of the perineum.

22.1 the ug and anal triangles next previous 4 for the purposes of description, the perineum is divided into the urogenital (ug) and anal triangles by the transtubercular line, an imaginary line that passes through the ischial tuberosities. orient the bony pelvis in the anatomical tas k the two triangles are not in the same plane. the ug triangle is in a horizontal plane, while the anal triangle faces almost posteriorly. the angle of flexion between the two triangles is the imaginary transtubercular line. look at the bony pelvis and model tas k from below, and define the three sides of these triangles. the ug triangle is defined by the transtubercular line, posteriorly, and the pubic arch anterolaterally. the anal triangle is defined by the transtubercular line anteriorly and the sacrotuberous ligaments, posterolaterally. position, with the asiss and the pubic tubercles in the coronal plane. look at the pelvis from the side and realize that

22.1 the pelvic diaphragm from the superior aspect next previous 5 remove the pelvic organs from the model. look through the pelvic inlet and identify tas k the muscles of the pelvic floor and wall. identify the pelvic diaphragm and its confirm that the line of attachment of the pelvic diaphragm to the inner wall of the true pelvis contacts the sacrum, posteriorly, crosses the ischial spines, bisects the obturator internis , and touches the pubic bones, anteriorly. the pelvic diaphragm separates the pelvis, above, from the perineum below. therefore, the pelvic diaphragm forms both the floor of the pelvis and the roof of the perineum. component parts, the levator ani and the coccygeus muscles. the coccygeus extends from the sacrum to the ischial spine, forming the posterior portions of the pelvic diaphragm. the fibres of the levator ani loop around the termini of the urogenital and digestive tracts, leaving a gap called the urogenital hiatus. identify in the model the urogenital hiatus and the openings for the passage of the urethra, vagina and anal canal. identify the obturator internis clothing the lateral wall of the pelvis. identify the piriformis arising from the anterior surface of the sacrum, posterior to the roots of the sciatic nerve. it clothes the posterior wall of the sacrum. the line of attachment of the levator ani, via this tendinous arch, bisects the obturator internis muscle such that the superior half of the obturator internis is in the true pelvis and the inferior half is in the perineum.

22a the perineal membrane and deep perineal pouch previous the perineal membrane extends between the conjoint rami within the ug triangle. it is a sheet of tough, dense, inextensible ct. its free posterior border extends between the ischial tuberosities. superior to the perineal membrane is the deep perineal pouch . it largely consists of skeletal muscle and neurovascular bundles. the superficial perineal pouch is inferior to the perineal membrane. *sigh* if ever a term was intended to confuse students, this is it. it is nothing like a pouch. its just a layer on the superior surface of the perineal membrane that includes skeletal muscles, nerves and blood vessels. the perineal membrane and deep perineal pouch close over the urogenital hiatus of the pelvic diaphragm, thereby completing the pelvic floor. in both sexes, an opening permits the passage of the urethra. in females, a second opening permits the passage of the vagina. in both sexes, the skeletal muscle of the deep perineal pouch includes the external urethral sphincter which provides voluntary control over micturition. external genitalia are tightly attached to the inferior surface of the perineal membrane and to the bony pubic arch. a hiatus between the anterior border of the perineal membrane and the pubic symphysis (blue arrow) permits the passage of neurovascular bundles from the deep perineal pouch to the clitoris and penis. 22.1 the pelvic diaphragm from the inferior aspect next previous 6 orient the model to look at it from below and notice that the ug triangle contains the tas k terminus of the urogenital tract and the anal triangle contains the terminus of the digestive tract. identify, extending between the ischial tuberosities anterior to the anus, the posterior border of the perineal membrane. the model shows it covered with its associated skeletal muscle. to review the description of the perineal membrane and deep perineal pouch, click here: now identify the pelvic diaphragm, which from this aspect, is seen to consist of the levator ani. identify the external anal sphincter.

22.1 the perinea in prosection next previous 7 unwrap the prosected perinea. sit them upside down on the table and study them from the tas k posterior aspect. in both, start by identifying the landmarks that define the pelvic outlet and perineum: the inferior border of the pubic symphysis, the coccyx, and the ischial tuberosities. now, identify the pelvic diaphragm; from this aspect only the levator ani is seen. observe that it is indeed shaped like a funnel, tapering to the anus, which represents its neck. note the fibres of the pelvic diaphragm looping around the anus; these surround and assist the function of the external anal sphincter. identify, stretching between the ischial tuberosities, anterior to the anus, the posterior border of the perineal membrane. pinch the perineal membrane with your thumbs and index fingers, bilaterally. realize that between your fingers is the deep perineal pouch, as well as the perineal membrane.

22.1 the perineal body next previous 8 the perineal body is a knot of ct that acts as an important point of attachment for muscles and connective tissue structures of both the pelvic floor (left) and the perineum (right). identify, at the midpoint of the posterior edge of the perineal membrane, the perineal body. tas k amongst other muscles, the levator ani attaches here, specifically the posterior border of the urogenital hiatus. the perineal body also provides attachment for muscles of the perineum in both the deep and superficial pouches.

22.1 the ischioanal fossae next 9 again, looking at the model from its inferior aspect, tas k identify the space lateral to the pelvic diaphragm and medial to the ischial tuberosities. these are the ischioanal fossae. in life, the ischioanal fossae are fat-filled spaces that permit the expansion of the anal canal during defecation. as you will learn, it also contains important nerves that innervate perineal structures, including the external anal sphincter and the external urethral sphincter. in the accompanying graphic, the funnel again represents the pelvic diaphragm. the cylinder that it rests in represents the bony pelvis. the inferior opening of the cylinder represents the pelvic outlet. the mouth of the funnel represents the line of attachment of the pelvic diaphragm to the wall of the pelvis. the space within and above the funnel represents the pelvic cavity. notice the space outside the funnel, but inside the cylinder. this represents a part of the perineum called the the ischioanal fossae. previous

22.1 the ischioanal fossae in the prosections next previous 10 turn your attention tas k back to the prosections. from the posterior aspect, insert your hands through the pelvic outlet, into the spaces on either side of the levator ani. your hands are in the ischioanal fossae of the anal triangle. feel the medial wall of the ischioanal fossa; it is the levator ani. feel the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa; you are touching the obturator internis muscle. feel the apex of the ischioanal fossa, where the medial wall (levator ani) meets the lateral wall (obturator internis), is at the tendinous arch of attachment of the levator ani to the obturator internis. appreciate that what is an empty space in the prosection, in life contains nerves, blood vessels and lymphatics packed in fat.

22.1 the anterior recesses of the ischioanal fossae next previous 11 slide your fingers anteriorly, from the tas k ischioanal fossae of the anal triangle into the urogenital triangle superior to the deep perineal pouch and perineal membrane. your fingers are in the anterior recesses of the ischioanal fossae. look at figure c. and perform the following exercise: touch the floor of the anterior recesses; you are touching the deep perineal pouch. touch the lateral walls of the anterior recesses; you are touching the obturator internis muscle. touch the medial wall of the anterior recesses; you are touching the levator ani. your fingers are in a dead-end space that ends at the pubis, to which both the perineal membrane and the levator ani attach. realize that the anterior recesses are extensions of the ischioanal fossae; these spaces are continuous with each other and filled with fat. they also, however contain important neurovascular elements that serve perineal structures, as you will see.

22a greater vestibular glands and bulbourethral glands previous 21 in women, the greater vestibular glands are located in the superficial perineal pouch. these pea-sized, mucus-secreting glands are located posterior to the bulbs of the vestibule. the ducts of the greater vestibular glands open into the vestibule and secrete mucus in response to sexual arousal. the male homologue of the greater vestibular glands are the bulbourethral glands. like the greater vestibular glands, the bulbourethral glands secrete mucus in response to sexual arousal. they are, however, located in the deep perineal pouch in contrast to the greater vestibular glands, which are located in the superficial perineal pouch. their ducts open into the urethra as it passes through the perineal membrane. eponym: bartholins glands 22a the bulb of the vestibule and the corpus spongiosum previous 20 in women, the space between the labia minora, into which the urethra and vagina open, is called the vestibule. a second pair of erectile bodies, thebulbs of the vestibule, surround this space bilaterally, fused to the inferior surface of the perineal membrane. tapered, anterior extensions of the bulbs of the vestibule meet in the midline, anterior to the urethral opening, as the glans clitoris. the male homologue of the bulbs of the vestibule is the corpus spongiosum, a single midline erectile body. its proximal end is enlarged as the bulb of the penis, and is fused to the inferior surface of the perineal membrane. its distal end joins the corpora cavernosa to complete the body of the penis, and expands to cover their distal ends as the glans penis. the male urethra extend through the corpus spongiosum to open at the tip of the glans penis at the external urethral orifice. by convention, in anatomical position, the penis is erect. therefore, the corpus spongiosum is described as being ventral to the corpora cavernosa, although their relationships are the opposite in the flaccid penis. 22a the superficial perineal pouch and corpora cavernosa previous 19 the portions of the ug triangle described thus far are the perineal membrane, deep perineal pouch and the anterior recesses of the ischioanal fossa. next is the region superficial to the perineal membrane. the region of the ug triangle between the membranous layer of superficial fascia and the perineal membrane is the superficial perineal pouch. this region contains the erectile structures of the external genitalia and associated skeletal muscles. in both sexes, bilaterally-paired erectile bodies, the corpora cavernosa , are fused to the ischiopubic rami, proximally. their distal, unfixed ends form the body of the clitoris in women, and contribute to the body of the penis in men. the proximal, attached ends of these erectile structures are called the crura of the clitoris or crura of the penis . singular: corpus cavernosum singular: crus 22.1 skeletal muscle of the perineum next previous 12 identify the ischiocavernosus muscles tas k on both prosections, overlying the crura of the clitoris and penis. on contraction, they propel blood from the crura to the body of the clitoris or penis. are two separate muscles. on the male prosection, however, note that the two bulbospongiosus muscles have fused in a midline raphe to cover over the bulb of the penis. in both sexes, the bulbospongiosus contracts to propel blood from the engorged bulb into more distal parts, including the glans. in men, the bulbospongiosus also i) assists with emptying the penile urethra following micturition, and ii) contracts reflexively during ejaculation, causing the pulsatile expulsion of semen from the penis. you will next study structures of the superficial perineal pouch in the prosection. if you wish, you may review the superficial perineal pouch and corpora cavernosa here: , the bulb of the vestibule and corpus spongiosum here: , and the greater vestibular and bulbourethral glands here: . three paired skeletal muscles occupy the superficial perineal pouch. two will be described. identify the bulbospongiosus muscles tas k on both prosections, extending from the perineal body to overlie the bulb(s) of the vestibule and penis. on the female prosection, note that the bulbospongiosus

22a autonomic nerves of the perineum previous 26 pelvic portions of the prevertebral plexus provide sympathetic, parasympathetic and visceral afferent fibres to pelvic structures and to the erectile tissues of the perineum. the pelvic portions of the prevertebral plexus are bilaterally paired and are referred to, variably, as the pelvic plexuses or the inferior hypogastric plexuses. the inferior hypogastric plexuses receive sympathetic fibres from the sacral splanchnic nerves, and parasympathetic fibres from the pelvic splanchnic nerves. the inferior hypogastric plexuses give rise to the rectal, uterovaginal, prostatic and vesical plexuses. the erectile tissues of the perineum are innervated by terminal branches of the inferior hypogastric plexuses that pass through the deep perineal pouch. in men, these are the cavernous nerves, derived from the prostatic plexus. in women these nerves are likely derived from the uterovaginal plexus. because of the close association of the cavernous nerves with the prostate, impotence can be a complication of prostatectomy. similarly, sexual dysfunction can be a complication in hysterectomy. previous 22a the pudendal nerve and the pelvic splanchnic nerve 24 because the pudendal nerves arise from the same spinal levels as the pelvic splanchnic nerves, students confuse them . a somatic nerve like, for example, the median nerve of the arm, intercostal nerves, and the femoral nerve of the leg the pelvic splanchnic nerves contain parasympathetic preganglionic fibres, the cell bodies of which are located in the intermediolateral cell column of the sacral spinal cord at the s2-s4 levels. the pelvic splanchnic nerves form on the posterior wall of the sacrum and feed into the inferior hypogastric plexus, from which their axons are distributed to the viscera of the distal digestive tract and pelvis. from the prostatic plexus, axons pass through the urogenital hiatus with the urethra to access the vascular smooth muscle of the erectile tissues of the penis and clitoris. these parasympathetic nerves are responsible for erection. the pudendal nerve is a somatic nerve . it contains the axons of lower motor neurons, the cell bodies of which are located in the ventral horns of the spinal cord at the s2-s4 levels. these axons are destined to innervate skeletal muscle of the perineum. it contains sensory fibres being distributed to the skin of the perineum and sympathetic postganglionic fibres that innervate vascular smooth muscle, as well as glands and erector pili muscle of the skin of the perineum. dont be that student! read on! 22a the pudendal nerve is a somatic nerve previous 23 the three major somatic nerves of the perineum are the inferior rectal nerve, the perineal nerve and the dorsal nerve of the penis / clitoris. these are all branches of the pudendal nerve. the pudendal nerve is formed on the posterior wall of the pelvis in the sacral plexus, by contributions from the s2, s3 and s4 ventral rami. the pudendal nerve is formed in the pelvis but innervates targets in the perineum. the pelvic diaphragm stands in its way, so the pudendal nerve exits the pelvis though the greater sciatic foramen, inferior to the piriformis, passes outside the sacrospinous ligament, and then enters the anal triangle through the lesser sciatic foramen. this is shown clearly here: the pudendal nerve travels along the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa, deep to the obturator fascia, in what is referred to as the pudendal canal. 22.1 somatic nerves of the perineum next previous 13 by its course: it will exit the greater sciatic foramen inferior to the piriformis, but medial to the sciatic nerve. it will cross the ischial spine, and then enter the anal triangle through the lesser sciatic foramen. it has three major branches; you are responsible for identifying only the first. reflect the gluteus maximus muscle in both prosections. identify the pudendal nerve. tas k on one or both sides of the prosection, the gluteus maximus muscle is cut, allowing you to study structures deep to it, including the pudendal nerve. if you wish, you may review the pudendal nerve here: . if you are not clear on the difference between the pudendal nerve and the pelvis splanchnic nerves, click here: . you are responsible for the distribution of all three: the inferior rectal nerve crosses the ischioanal fossa to innervate the external anal sphincter and portions of the levator ani and the skin of the anal triangle. the perineal nerve enters the superficial perineal pouch to innervate its skeletal muscle, the skin of the urogenital triangle and ends as the cutaneous posterior scrotal / labial nerves. the third branch traverses the deep perineal pouch to end as the dorsal nerve of the penis / clitoris. you may review the autonomic innervation of the perineum here: .

in portal hypertension, as might occur in cirrhosis of the liver, venous pressure in portocaval anastomoses is elevated, causing venous engorgement and increased likelihood of bleeding. 22.1 the internal pudendal artery and vein next previous 14 in the companionship of the pudendal nerve, passing through the greater sciatic foramen, around the ischial spine, and through the identify the internal pudendal artery / vein tas k the internal pudendal artery arises in the pelvis as a branch of the internal iliac artery. it, and its branches, have companion veins of the same name . lesser sciatic foramen into the anal triangle. notice that at the ischial spine, the pudendal nerve is most medial. the internal pudendal artery and vein branch with the pudendal nerve. identify the inferior rectal arteries / veins accompanying the inferior rectal nerves across the ischioanal fossa to the rectum. these vessels anastomose with the middle rectal arteries and veins from the internal iliac, and the superior rectal arteries and veins from the inferior mesenteric. the venous anastomosis is a significant site of portocaval anastomosis . perineal arteries and veins accompany the perineal nerves into the superficial pouch. the internal pudendal artery and vein ends by supplying the structures of the deep pouch and erectile tissue.
congratulations on finishing lab 22.1 the perineum! review exercise 22.1 review exercise 22.1 review exercise 22.1 previous back to labs selection back to labs selection back to labs selection

22.4 pelvic viscera previous specimens prosected half pelves, male and female male and female cadavers with undissected pelves next what youll need: instructions students who begin the lab session at this station will unwrap the two prosections as instructed. students who finish at this station will moisten, wrap, bag and properly tag these prosections. proper care of prosections remember, you must not dissect a prosection. use only blunt instruments to examine a prosection.

22.4 objectives next previous 2 when you have completed the exercises described here, you will be able to identify and describe the pelvic viscera and their relationships to the gastrointestinal, urinary and reproductive systems.

22a the digestive tract in the pelvis previous in both sexes, in the posterior midline of the pelvis, are the distal portions of the digestive tract: the terminal sigmoid colon, the rectum and the anal canal. the rectum, and in particular its ampulla, functions to store feces prior to evacuation. the puborectal subdivision of the levator ani pulls the anorectal junction forward, imposing a 90 bend at this point in the digestive tract. this creates a pinch valve that assists in the maintenance of fecal continence. during defecation, the levator ani relaxes, and the rectoanal junction straightens, to facilitate evacuation. another consequence of the normal tone in the levator ani is that the anal canal is oriented posteriorly as it passes into the perineum. along its length, the anal canal is surrounded by the internal and external anal sphincters. the internal anal sphincter is smooth, involuntary muscle, integral to the wall of the anal canal. the external anal sphincter is a ring of striated, voluntary muscle located within the perineum. 22.4 the digestive and urinary tracts in the pelvis next previous 3 to review the components of the digestive tract in the pelvis, click here: unwrap both prosections. tas k identify the rectum, its junction with the anal canal, and therefore the location of the pelvic diaphragm. identify, in both prosections, the ureter where it enters the pelvic inlet by crossing anterior to the bifurcation of the common iliac artery. the ureters cross the posterior wall of the pelvis to pierce the base of the urinary bladder. identify the urinary bladder, noting that in both sexes it takes up the most anterior position in the pelvis, being located immediately posterior to the pubic symphysis. the bladder, when empty, is located in the true pelvis. when full, however, it expands into the abdomen. identify the base and superior surface of the urinary bladder. recall that the urinary bladder is a triangular pyramid, with its base oriented posteriorly, its apex oriented anteriorly, a superior surface and two inferolateral surfaces . identify the neck of the bladder, which surrounds the origin of the urethra, and contains the internal urethral sphincter, composed of smooth, involuntary muscle.

22.4 the female urethra next previous 4 identify, in the prosected female pelvis, the urethra extending from the tas k internal urethral orifice at the neck of the bladder, through the pelvic floor, to open into the vestibule at the external urethral orifice. as the urethra passes through the pelvic floor it is surrounded by the striated, voluntary external urethral sphincter. identify the labium minus; the labia minora from the borders of the vestibule, the space into which the urethra and vagina open. notice the relatively short length of the urethra in the female; at 4 cm it is significantly shorter than the male urethra. notice that the urethra is anterior to the vagina, and that the two are joined by ct. you will be unable to identify the para-urethral (skenes) glands, paired mucus-secreting glands that open into the terminal urethra.

22a the male urethra and prostate gland previous in the male, the urethra extends from the internal urethral orifice at the neck of the bladder, through the prostate gland, the pelvic floor, and the corpus spongiosum of the penis to open at the external urethral orifice of the glans. the prostate gland surrounds the neck of the bladder, which contains the internal urethral sphincter. contraction of this sphincter in emission prevents the passage of semen into the bladder. this sphincter may be compromised in prostatectomy. in the prostatic part of the urethra are the roughly 50 openings of the ducts of the prostate gland . also present here are the bilaterally-paired openings of the ejaculatory ducts, at which point the urinary and reproductive systems of the male unite. as with the female urethra, the male urethra is surrounded by the striated, voluntary external urethral sphincter as it passes through the pelvic floor. located in the pelvic floor are the mucus-secreting bulbo-urethral glands, the duct of which opens into the proximal portion of the penile (spongy) urethra. in total, the male urethra is roughly 20 cm in length 22.4 the male urethra and prostate gland next previous 5 identify, in the prosected male pelvis, the urethra extending from the tas k internal urethral orifice at the neck of the bladder, through the prostate gland, the pelvic floor, and the corpus spongiosum of the penis to open at the external urethral orifice of the glans. notice that the prostate gland surrounds the neck of the bladder, which contains the internal urethral sphincter. contraction of this sphincter in emission prevents the passage of semen into the bladder. this sphincter may be compromised in prostatectomy. to review the anatomy of the male urethra and prostate gland, click here:

22a the female reproductive tract and uterus previous the components of the female reproductive tract are located primarily in the true pelvis, although in pregnancy, the uterus ascends into the abdomen. components of the internal genitalia are the ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus and vagina. the external genitalia consists of the clitoris. associated with the female reproductive tract is a pair of accessory glands, the greater vestibular glands. the uterus is dominated by a thick, muscular wall. it is subdivided into a body and a cervix. the body of the uterus is continuous superolaterally with the bilaterally-paired uterine tubes. the cap-like portion of the uterus superior to the opening of the uterine tubes is the fundus. the cervix is continuous, inferiorly, with the vagina. 22.4 the uterus and broad ligament next previous 6 identify, in prosected female pelvis, tas k the uterus located between the bladder and the rectum. identify its visceral peritoneum. in the midline, trace the reflection of its peritoneum anteriorly onto the superior surface of the bladder, forming the vesicouterine pouch, and posteriorly onto the anterior surface of the rectum forming the rectouterine pouch. trace its visceral peritoneum laterally to where it forms the broad ligament. in the superior margin of the broad ligament, identify the fallopian tube. on the posterior aspect of the broad ligament, identify the ovary, which will be white and about the size of a finger tip. identify the subdivisions of the broad ligament, the mesovarium, which extends to the ovary, the mesosalpinx which extends from the mesovarium to the uterine tube , and the mesometrium, which extends from the mesovarium to the uterus. recall that salpinx means tube. to review the components of the female reproductive tract and uterus, click here:

22a the ovaries and fallopian tubes previous in the female embryo, the gubernaculum connects the female gonad to the labium majus, the female homologue of the scrotum. the remnants of the gubernaculum in the female are the ligament of the ovary and the round ligament, the latter passing through the inguinal canal to the labium majus. the uterine tubes extend laterally from the superolateral aspect of the uterus. the uterine tubes are end as the expanded infundibulum of the uterine tube with its fimbriae. the uterine tube opens into the peritoneal cavity, and eggs released by the ovary must be drawn into the lumen of the uterine tube. the most common site of fertilization is in the ampulla of the uterine tube; the conceptus then passing along its isthmus and intramural portion to access the uterine cavity. in the embryo, the ovaries originate high up in the posterior abdominal wall, and that they migrate, prenatally, to their ultimate position in the pelvis. this is analogous to the descent of the testes in the male, although the ovaries do not migrate into the perineum. ovarian nerves, vessels and lymphatics are located in the suspensory ligament of the ovary, and travel back, through the posterior abdominal wall, to the embryonic level of origin of the ovaries. 22.4 the ovaries and fallopian tubes next previous 7 identify, again, in the prosected female hemi-pelvis, the ovary. tas k identify its suspensory ligament, the ligament of the ovary and the round ligament. gently pull the fallopian tube superiorly, and confirm the position of the ovary on the posterior surface of the broad ligament. to review the anatomy of the ovaries and fallopian tubes, click here: identify, again, in the prosected female hemi-pelvis, the uterine tubes . notice their course from the superolateral aspect of the uterus laterally, within the superior margin of the broad ligament. observe that the uterine tube terminates lateral to the ovary, and so turns back to meet its surface. identify the expanded infundibulum of the uterine tube and its fimbriae. realize that the uterine tube opens into the peritoneal cavity, and that eggs released by the ovary must be drawn into the lumen of the uterine tube. the most common site of fertilization is in the ampulla of the uterine tube; the conceptus then passing along its isthmus and intramural portion to access the uterine cavity.

22.4 the cervix and vagina next previous 8 confirm that the body of the uterus lies tas k superior to the bladder. identify the cervix and vagina. note that the thick wall of the cervix bulges into the proximal end of the thin-walled vaginal canal. identify the vaginal fornix, the recess surrounding the cervix where it is continuous with the wall of the vagina. identify the internal os where the uterine cavity is continuous with the cervical canal, and the external os, where the cervical canal meets the vaginal canal. confirm that the anterior wall of the vagina lies adjacent to the base of the bladder and urethra. note that the vagina and urethra pass from the pelvis, through the pelvic floor to the perineum, where both structures open into the vestibule. confirm that the posterior wall of the vagina lies against the rectum , separated by the rectovaginal septum. because the vaginal canal is normally collapsed, a physician uses a speculum to open the vagina in order to view the cervix, fornix and external os (see lower figure). os mouth

22.4 the female pelvis in the cadaver next previous 9 uncover this cadaver and identify tas k the following structures and spaces, already identified in the female half pelvis: one female cadaver has been identified in your lab that contains internal genitalia. many have had these organs removed during their lifetime in a hysterectomy. the rectum, flanked by the para-rectal fossae, the uterus, the superior surface of the bladder, the rectouterine pouch, the vesicouterine pouch the uterine peritoneum, the fallopian tubes, including the fimbria, infundibulum, and ampulla, the ovaries, the broad ligament, including the mesovarium, mesosalpinx and mesometrium the suspensory ligament of the ovaries, the ovarian ligament and the round ligament of the uterus

22.4 the male pelvis next previous 10 this is a brief review of the male pelvis to be conducted in both the half pelvis and the male cadaver. identify, in the male pelvis, tas k the following structures: the rectum, flanked by the para-rectal fossae, the superior surface of the bladder, the rectovesical pouch in the cadaver, identify the vas deferens coursing deep to the parietal peritoneum from the deep inguinal ring, along the pelvic wall toward the base of the bladder.

lymphatic drainage of the pelvis 22a venous and lymphatic drainage of the pelvis 40 in general, pelvic veins follow their companion arteries and take the same names. pelvic veins drain into the internal iliac vein, which ascends over the pelvic brim and joins the external iliac vein to form the common iliac vein. interconnecting networks of venous plexuses surround the pelvic viscera, forming the vesical, rectal, uterine, vaginal and prostatic venous plexuses. a tributary of the prostatic plexus in males, and of the vesical plexus in females, is the deep dorsal vein of the penis / clitoris. it drains venous blood from these erectile tissues directly into the pelvis by passing between the posterior margin of the pubic symphysis and the anterior margin of the perineal membrane. lymph nodes associated with the internal iliac arteries receive lymph from pelvic and deep perineal structures. lymph nodes associated with the external iliac arteries receive lymph from the superficial and deep inguinal nodes. lymph nodes associated with the common iliac arteries receive lymph from both these groups of nodes, and convey it superiorly into the lateral aortic / lumbar nodes. these drain into the lumbar trunks, which empty into the cisterna chyle. it continues superiorly as the thoracic duct. venous drainage of the pelvis previous the female anterior trunk 22a the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery 39 in males, each anterior trunk gives rise to a(n): superior and inferior vesical artery, supplying the bladder, ureter, seminal vesicles and prostate gland. inferior gluteal artery, which contributes to the blood supply of the gluteal region. middle rectal artery, supplying the rectum, along with the superior rectal artery from the inferior mesenteric artery and the inferior rectal arteries from the internal pudendal arteries. obturator artery, which enters the medial compartment of the thigh via the obturator canal. internal pudendal artery, which exits the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen and enters the perineum via the lesser sciatic foramen to supply perineal structures. in females: in place of an inferior vesicle artery, women have a vaginal artery, which supplies the vagina and adjacent parts of the bladder, urethra and rectum. the uterine artery is a major branch that runs in the base of the broad ligament to the cervix, where it anastomoses with the vaginal artery. there the vaginal artery turns to ascend along the lateral aspect of the uterus, and runs along the uterine tubes, where it ends in an anastomosis with the ovarian artery. the male anterior trunk previous 22a the internal iliac artery and posterior trunk 38 the internal iliac artery supplies blood to the pelvis and perineum, as well as sending branches to the gluteal region and medial thigh. recall, however, that in both sexes, the gonadal arteries are derived from the abdominal aorta. the internal iliac artery arises at the bifurcation of the common iliac artery at the level of the l5-s1 disc. it enters the pelvic inlet and itself bifurcates into anterior and posterior trunks. the posterior trunk gives rise to branches that supply the posterior abdominal and pelvic walls and the gluteal region. previous 22a autonomic nerves of the pelvis 37 pelvic portions of the prevertebral plexus provide sympathetic, parasympathetic and visceral afferent fibres to pelvic structures and to the erectile tissues of the perineum. the pelvic portions of the prevertebral plexus are bilaterally paired and are referred to, variably, as the pelvic plexuses or the inferior hypogastric plexuses. the inferior hypogastric plexuses receive sympathetic fibres from the sacral splanchnic nerves, and parasympathetic fibres from the pelvic splanchnic nerves. the inferior hypogastric plexuses give rise to the rectal, uterovaginal, prostatic and vesical plexuses. sympathetic fibres in these plexuses are responsible for vascular tone, contraction of smooth muscle sphincters of the anus and urethra, contraction of smooth muscle in the walls of the reproductive tracts and their accessory glands, including during emission in males. parasympathetic fibres in these plexuses are responsible for contraction of the detrusor muscle of the bladder, motility of the distal digestive tract, and relaxation of smooth muscle in erectile tissues, which results in engorgement and erection. previous 22.4 nerves, blood vessels and lymphatics of the pelvis next previous 11 you now have the opportunity to review, with your group, the autonomic innervation of the pelvis , the internal iliac artery and its posterior trunk , the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery and its branches , and the venous and lymphatic drainage of the pelvis .

22.3 objectives next previous when you have learned the content of this emodule, you will be able to identify and / or describe the: bones that form the pelvis structure of the articulated pelvis structural differences between the male and female pelvis 2

22.3 the os coxa next previous the pelvis is formed by four bones, the two ossa coxae (hip bones), the sacrum and the coccyx. you will start this exercise with a review of the bony components of the pelvis. ossa (pl), os (s) bone coxae (pl), coxa (s) hip pick up a hip bone tas k from the bones with which youve been provided. identify its lateral surface by finding the acetabulum, which articulates with the head of the femur to form the hip joint. the hip bone is formed from three bones that are separate, but joined by cartilage, at birth; they fuse with physical maturity. identify these subdivisions: tas k ilium ischium pubis 3

22.3 features of the os coxa next previous on the lateral surface tas k of the hip bone, identify the features indicated on the accompanying diagram. g5.21b 4 turn the bone over, tas k and on the medial surface of the hip bone, identify the features indicated on this diagram: .

22.3 joints of the pelvis next previous pick up the sacrum tas k from amongst the bones with which youve been provided and articulate it with the hip bone in your hand, grays atlas p.202 5 thus demonstrating the sacroiliac joint. the sacroiliac joint is a synovial joint, reinforced by massive ligaments, the interosseous sacroiliac ligament, and the anterior and posterior sacroiliac ligaments. tas k and articulate it with the first to demonstrate the location of the pubic symphysis . the symphyseal surfaces of the pubic bones are covered by articular cartilage and are joined by a fibrocartilagenous disc, much like an intervertebral disc. the joint is reinforced by superior and inferior pubic ligaments. pick up the second hip bone,

22.3 the true and false pelvis next previous turn your attention to the model of a bony pelvis with which you have been provided. identify the larger, upper bowl, the false pelvis. tas k it borders the lower abdominal wall and contains abdominal organs. identify the smaller, lower bowl, the true pelvis. it contains pelvic organs. identify the plane that separates the false and true pelvis; this is the pelvic inlet. 6 run your fingers around the margin of the pelvic inlet. this is the pelvic brim . identify the bony features that contribute to it, as illustrated in the figure. hold the pelvis in anatomical position, as in the figure , by placing the asis and the pubic tubercles in the same vertical plane. notice the orientation of the pelvic inlet: it is tipped very much forward and the body of the pubis is facing inferiorly, rather than anteriorly.

22.3 muscles of the pelvic wall next previous foramina (pl), foramen (s) opening; usually through a bony or ligamentous structure 7 the wall of the pelvis is clothed with two lateral rotators of the hip that originate within the pelvis, then exit to cross the back of the hip joint to the region of the greater trochanter. these are the piriformis and the obturator internis. the piriformis originates on the anterior surface of the sacrum and exits the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen. recall that the piriformis is the key to the region, and that the nerves and vessels that exit the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen are land-marked according to their position relative to this muscle. recall that the obturator membrane serves to provide surface area for muscular attachment. the obturator internis muscle originates on its internal surface and passes out of the pelvis via the lesser sciatic foramen.

23.1 the internal pudendal artery and vein travel with the pudendal nerve 22a the pelvic diaphragm separates the pelvis from the perineum previous 8 the pelvic diaphragm physically separates the pelvis from the perineum. this creates a problem for any structures that must pass between these two body regions; the pelvic diaphragm is in the way! the line of attachment of the pelvic diaphragm is illustrated in this figure. notice that this line crosses the ischial spine and sacrospinous ligament. because of this: the greater sciatic foramen connects the pelvis with the gluteal region, and the lesser sciatic foramen is connects the gluteal region with the perineum. structures that originate in the pelvis, but are destined to enter the perineum, pass out of the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen inferior to the piriformis, and into the perineum via the lesser sciatic foramen. this is illustrated in this figure using the pudendal nerve, a somatic nerve dedicated to the skeletal muscle and skin of the perineum. examples of vessels solving the same conundrum in a similar manner are shown here , but with the pelvic diaphragm, obturator internis and the piriformis in place. 22a the pelvic diaphragm 7 the levator ani originates from the posterior aspect of the pubic bone, lateral to the pubic symphysis, and along a tendinous arch that extends to the ischial spine, bisecting the obturator internis. the latter attachment ensures that the superior portion of the obturator internis contributes to the lateral wall of the pelvis and the inferior portion contributes to the lateral wall of the perineum. some fibres of the levator ani attach to the coccyx via the anococcygeal ligament while others loop around the anal aperture. still other fibres meet in the midline anterior to the anal aperture, leaving a midline gap, the urogenital hiatus, through which the urethra passes in both sexes, and through which the vagina passes in females. levator ani you are not responsible for the names of its subdivisions. the levator ani muscles support pelvic viscera and contribute to fecal continence. the coccygeus muscles complete the pelvic diaphragm, posteriorly. they are triangular, extending from a broad base on the anterior surface of the coccyx to the ischial spine. they overly the sacrospinous ligament. the pelvic diaphragm consists of two muscles: the levator ani and the coccygeus, which form a bowl-shaped partition separating the pelvis and perineum. previous 22.3 the pelvic outlet and pelvic diaphragm next the sacrotuberous ligaments contribute to the margin of the pelvic outlet, along with the ischiopubic rami, the pubic symphysis and the coccyx. 8 hold the pelvis as in this illustration and identify these bony landmarks tas k most of the pelvic outlet is enclosed by the pelvic diaphragm, a funnel-shaped sheet of skeletal muscle that separates the true pelvis from the perineum. the perineum is defined as the region between the thighs, below the pelvic diaphragm. you may review the relationship between the pelvic diaphragm and the pelvic wall here: . you may review the relationship between the pelvic diaphragm, pelvic cavity and perineum here: . previous

23.1 the internal pudendal artery and vein travel with the pudendal nerve 22.3 the pelvic diaphragm is like a funnel next previous 9 notice that the funnel separates the pelvis from the perineum. youve also been provided with 3 pipe cleaners. these represent the twigs of the s2, s3 and s4 ventral rami that come together to form the pudendal nerve. twist much of the pipe cleaners together to create the pudendal nerve. pass this nerve out of the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen and into the perineum through the lesser sciatic foramen. this path is taken by vessels , as well as nerves, from the pelvis to the perineum. it is very important to understand! boy, i got some looks, buying this many funnels! place the funnel into the pelvis provided. tas k ensure that the rim of the funnel: contacts the s5 vertebral body crosses the sacrospinous ligament bisects the obturator foramen you are provided with a red silicone funnel . its bowl represents the pelvic diaphragm and the notch cut out of it represents the urogenital hiatus.

22a the difference between the male and female pelves previous largely to accommodate childbirth, the female pelvis is different from the male pelvis. the pelvis in the female has a larger, more circular pelvic inlet; that of the male pelvis is often described as, heart shaped, because the sacral promontory impinges on the pelvic inlet from the posterior aspect. the distance between the ischial spines is the narrowest point in the birth canal. this dimension is smaller in men, because the ischial spines in the male pelvis are more prominent and project more medially into the true pelvis. the infrapubic angle is larger in women than in men. this results in greater separation of the ischial tuberosities, which widens the pelvic outlet for passage of a baby 9 23.3 the difference between the male and female pelves next previous 10 look at the pelvis model tas k at your station. does it represent a male or a female pelvis? if you need reminding of the difference between the male and female pelvis, click here: . a womans ability to safely deliver vaginally is predicted by the size of her pelvic inlet and outlet. using the pelvis and your fingers, define the following dimensions . the pelvic inlet is defined by the: maximum transverse diameter of the inlet (a), and the sagittal inlet (b), measured between the sacral promontory and the top of the pubic symphysis. the pelvic outlet is defined by the: bispinous outlet (c), the distance between the ischial spines, which is the narrowest lateral dimension of the pelvic outlet, and the sagittal outlet (d), the distance between the coccyx and the bottom of the pubic symphysis
